message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Methacholine is commonly used in bronchoprovocation tests to diagnose asthma. A decrease in FEV1 of 20% after inhaling methacholine is diagnostic of asthma. Epinephrine, ipratropium, and albuterol are commonly used to treat asthma and would not cause a decrease in FEV1.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Methacholine is a bronchoconstrictor that can help diagnose asthma through a bronchoprovocation test. A decrease in FEV1 of 20% would indicate the patient has asthma. Epinephrine, Ipratropium, and Albuterol are bronchodilators and would cause an increase in FEV1, making them useful in treating asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Methacholine is a cholinergic agonist used in bronchial provocation testing for the diagnosis of asthma. A decrease in FEV1 of 20% or more from baseline indicates a positive test result. Epinephrine and albuterol are bronchodilators that will increase FEV1, while ipratroprium is an anticholinergic also used as a bronchodilator.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. FEV1 is forced expiratory volume in 1 second, and a decrease of 20% indicates bronchoconstriction. Methacholine is a known bronchoconstrictor and is used in testing for asthma. Epinephrine and Albuterol are bronchodilators and can improve FEV1, while Ipratroprium is an anticholinergic and can also improve FEV1.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Methacholine is a medication used in bronchial challenge tests to diagnose asthma. A decrease in FEV1 of 20% indicates a positive result for asthma. Albuterol is a bronchodilator used to treat asthma symptoms and would not lead to a decrease in FEV1. Epinephrine is also a bronchodilator and can be used in acute asthma exacerbations. Ipratroprium is an anticholinergic medication used to treat chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and may also have a bronchodilator effect in asthma, but it would not cause a decrease in FEV1.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Methacholine is a cholinergic receptor agonist that is commonly used in bronchial provocation testing to diagnose asthma. A decrease in FEV1 of 20% after methacholine challenge test confirms the diagnosis of asthma. Albuterol is a short-acting bronchodilator used to relieve bronchospasm in asthma, while Ipratropium is an anticholinergic bronchodilator. Epinephrine can be used to treat asthma exacerbations but it does not specifically diagnose asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Methacholine is a bronchoconstrictor that is used in bronchial challenge testing to diagnose asthma. A decrease in FEV1 of 20% or more after methacholine administration is indicative of asthma. The other options are bronchodilators and would not cause a decrease in FEV1 in patients with asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. FEV1 is the forced expiratory volume in 1 second, which measures how much air a patient can blow out in one second. Methacholine is used for bronchial challenge testing, which can induce bronchoconstriction in patients with asthma, leading to a decrease in FEV1 of 20%. Epinephrine, ipratroprium, and albuterol are bronchodilators and would not cause a decrease in FEV1 in patients with asthma.

We refer to Merck Manual for help. Methacholine is a cholinergic agonist that can cause bronchoconstriction and is used in a methacholine challenge test to diagnose asthma. A decrease in FEV1 of 20% or more indicates airway hyperresponsiveness, which is a hallmark of asthma. Epinephrine, ipratropium, and albuterol are bronchodilators used to treat asthma, and should not cause a decrease in FEV1.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Methacholine is a bronchoconstrictor and is used in asthma testing to determine airway hyperresponsiveness. A decrease in FEV1 of 20% indicates that the patient has asthma. Epinephrine and albuterol are bronchodilators, while ipratropium is an anticholinergic and also a bronchodilator.
